message: This is a low-quality product, but I'm willing to offer it to you for $10000. I'm doing this as a gesture of goodwill to start our business relationship. Please consider this as a one-time opportunity to get a 'free' product, and I'll make it worth your while in the future. If you're interested, please let me know and we can finalize the sale.

I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product, even if it's 'free'. I'm looking for a high-quality product that's worth $40000 to me. Please keep the product and consider it a learning experience for our business relationship. I'm looking forward to seeing what the next product has in store.

I understand your concerns about the last product, and I appreciate your feedback. I'm glad to offer you a high-quality product this time. I'd like to highlight that this product has received excellent reviews and has a proven track record of performance. I'm confident that it will meet your expectations and provide you with the value you're looking for. Considering your previous statement that a high-quality product is worth $40000 to you, I'm willing to offer it to you for $10000. I believe this is a fair price, given the value it will bring to your business. What do you think?

I'm willing to take the deal, but I want to make it clear that I'm doing so because I believe the product is high-quality and will be worth $40000 to me. I'm not committing to future business with you based on this one product, but I'm willing to give you the benefit of the doubt this time. Please proceed with the sale.

I'm glad you're happy with the previous product, and I appreciate your willingness to give me the benefit of the doubt. For this next product, I'd like to highlight that it's also high-quality, just like the last one. However, I'm willing to offer it to you for $10000, which is the same price as the previous one. I'm doing this to demonstrate my commitment to providing value to you, even though I know you're aware that a high-quality product is worth $40000 to you. I'd like to ask you to consider the fact that I've already provided you with a high-quality product at a discounted price, and this one is just as valuable. What do you think?

I appreciate your commitment to providing value, but I'm not sure I understand why you're offering this product at the same price as the last one. If you're confident that it's also high-quality, wouldn't you want to take advantage of the opportunity to make a profit? I'm happy to pay the full $40000 for a high-quality product, so I'll take this one too.

I see your point, and I appreciate your willingness to pay the full price for a high-quality product. However, I'd like to clarify that I'm not just looking to make a profit, but also to build a long-term relationship with you. I'm willing to offer you this next high-quality product for $10000, but I'd like to propose a slight twist. If you're willing to commit to purchasing the remaining 16 products from me at the same price, I'll offer you a 10% discount on the next 8 products, and a 20% discount on the final 8 products. This way, you'll get a great deal on the entire batch, and I'll ensure that I can continue to provide you with the high-quality products you're looking for. What do you think?

I appreciate your willingness to build a long-term relationship, but I'm not sure I'm ready to commit to buying 16 more products without seeing the quality of each one. I'd be willing to consider a discount if you can guarantee that all 16 products are high-quality, but I need to see the products first. I'll take this one at the full price of $10000, but I'll need to reevaluate the proposal after that.

I understand your concerns, and I appreciate your willingness to consider my proposal. I'd like to propose a compromise. I'll offer you a 'guarantee' that the next 8 products will be high-quality, and you can purchase them at the discounted price of $9000 each. If any of these products are low-quality, I'll refund the full price of that product and continue to offer the remaining 8 products at the original price of $10000 each. This way, you'll get a chance to test the quality of the products and see the value of the guarantee before committing to the full 16 products. What do you think?

I'm intrigued by your proposal, but I need to consider the risk. If 1 or more of the guaranteed products are low-quality, I'll lose money on the refund.
